div3.head: A Christmas story for the young.
div3.p: My dear young friends, some of you may have read a beautiful story by a pious minister, about earth's angels; how day and night, week after week, and year after year, one of the purest and brightest of the angels kneels ever before heaven, pouring tears of sorrow for the sins of men, and praying ever that God will forgive them, and offering up his burning love and passionate tears to stone for our coldness and wickedness; and this angel sees so much sin and so little love upon earth, that he is always weeping most bitterly for the outraged honor of his dear Lord our Saviour, and lamenting the sins and sorrows of men.--All the angels in heaven have some particular province, that is, some particular work to do, and this is the work of this dear angel; and because he is always interceding for us, he is called earth's angel.

The tears of this dear angel form a bright limpid stream before the throne of the great God, always pure and calm, but one Christmas eve, when all the happy angels in heaven were singing most beautiful hosannas, and the whole court of heaven were prostrate before the once Babe of Bethlehem, this stream of the angel's tears was agitated, and its silvery sweetness was moved by little waves that sobbed and sighed mournfully; and dear St. Mary cast her sweet eyes upon the sad pleading waters, and she sent a bright messenger to inquire why earth's angel was so grieved on Christmas eve.

The dear angel said he grieved bitterly this night for the sorrows and miseries of little children; some were dying with hunger and cold, some poor little babies were dying un-baptized, and alas!
for their little souls, others were growing older and learning to commit sin; the lips that God made to love Him and praise Him were beginning to speak against him, to speak falsely and unkindly, and, oh!
some to curse and swear.
The hands God made to be raised in prayer and employed in good, kind deeds, were used in anger and in dishonesty, and, alas!
the little heart God made to serve Him, was learning to neglect Him and love His enemies.
Other children were good, but very miserable, and the dear angel's soul was sad on their account, and the tears dropped faster and faster into the overflowing stream.
Then St. Mary spoke to Him who had once been a little child, and she begged His mercy and compassion upon the suffering children of earth.

And Mary's voice sounded through heaven clear and melodious, like the beautiful strings of a golden harp, or the sweet dreamy music of the wind on a summer's night.
When she ceased speaking there was silence in heaven, for the angels loved to hear the last echo as it softly died away.

Our Lord granted her prayer as soon as it was asked.
He always does so, dear children, and he took compassion upon some of the children and relieved their little sufferings, and then He sent an angel down to earth to bring the most miserable child he could find to heaven.

The angel bowed his bright head before his Lord, and hastened to obey his command.--The world was very fair, it wore its white robe of Christmas snow, but it looked dreary and dull, when compared with the beautiful golden heaven the angel left behind; and on his way he passed earth's angel, who gave him one of his tears, and it was so large and bright that if he held the little finger on which he carried it near the heart of a child, he could see by its light all that was passing within.

He alighted in one of the largest cities in England, because he knew there is always more misery in those great places than in small towns or villages.
At first, the angel was almost bewildered by the busy crowds, as they hurried along the streets; for, under the rich dresses and poor rags, the warm clothing and thin, beauty covering, he could see the human hearts beating, and could read all their thoughts; and when he saw what was passing in the minds of some who were well to look at and fair to view, this dear angel sighed and turned away his beautiful head, and said, "Alas!" for the dear honor and wounded love of his blessed Lord.
He passed on through the light streets, filled with gay shop-windows, and thronged by busy men and women He came to some large, grand houses, all brilliantly lighted and full of festivity. "I do not think I shall find a very miserable child here," said the angel, "but I will go in and see" So he went through a spacious hall, and up a large marble staircase, through magnificently furnished rooms, and he passed splendidly-dressed ladies on his way, until he came to the nursery — for every angel, when he enters a house, goes first where the children are. It was a large warm room, with a thick, soft carpet upon the floor, and crimson curtains to the window, which gave a rich, glowing color to the light.
No one seemed to be in the room, until, looking in one corner, he saw a little boy, about seven years old, who had cried himself to sleep.
His toys were all laying about, as though he did not care for them; one little hand grasped a small figure of a dog, two great round tears lay upon his pretty cheeks, and every few minutes a deep sigh made his sweet lips tremble.

Three years ago this little boy had a dear mother, who loved him as all mothers love their children.
She used to nurse him and sing to him; and she had long golden curls that he used to play with; and every night she used to come and put his hands together, and teach him his prayers, and then draw the white curtains around his pretty bed, and kiss him many times over, and say, "Good night." The little boy saw his mother's sweet face was very white one night, and she kissed him so often that he wondered; and the next day she was ill, and after some time they carried him to her, where she lay so white and faint, that he was frightened, and began to cry, but she clasped him in her weak arms, and held him there until some one gave a great cry, and the dear arms fell down.
And after that he never saw his mother again — they said she was gone to heaven.
Some time after, his father brought a new mamma home, but she was not like his own: she had dark hair, and such black eyes, and she did not seem to love him very much; so the little boy was very lonely: no one came at night to kiss him or hear his prayers, only the nursemaid, and she was cross, and used to frighten him with foolish tales.
And on Christmas eve he sat and thought about his dear mother, with her sweet face and golden hair, until he cried himself to sleep.
The angel knelt by him, and saw by the light all that was passing in his breast.
It was not all sorrow; oh, no; for there was much love to cheer the boy for his mother in heaven, and while any one who loves a mother in heaven he cannot be quite miserable.
So the angel blessed the pretty sleeper and left him. He then went down a narrow court, where the houses were so poor that you would think no one could live in them.
In the very poorest of these the angel went.
The window was broken and stopped with rags, and the cold air came in; there was very little fire, only just a few dying embers, and no furniture but a heap of straw in one corner, and one old stool before the fire.
By the light of the wretched candle the angel saw upon the heap of straw a child, fearfully ill, its face flushed and hot, and its eyes heavy and dull.
On the stool sat a poor woman cowering over the fire, trying in vain to get some heat or warmth from it. And every time the child moaned the mother crossed herself, as though otherwise she should despair.
And then the little weak voice said:

q.p: "Oh, mother, give me some tea, I am burning with thirst."
"I have not got it, darling," said the woman, with a passionate cry, as she fell upon her knees. "I have nothing to give you but water."

div3.p: Then the angel knelt and locked in the child's heart; poverty, cold, hunger, thirst, and sickness, had all tried their worst, and yet for that child there was a light in its darkness --In the midst of its pains and troubles it loved its mother, and had great pleasure in her tenderness and love.
"The child is not quite miserable, I must go elsewhere," he said.

In another house, a little boy was pursing his little dying sister, and the poor mother was busy cleaning up the house for the doctor, and the little boy's tears fell hot and fast upon the pretty pale baby that he loved so dearly, and was so soon going to lose forever.
But he was pleased, because he knew the dear, dying baby would soon be in heaven.
So the angel left him, and he looked up to the sky, where the stars were gleaming, and he heard the hosannas of the angels and the ripple of the stream of tears.

And while he was looking upwards he heard a sound of music near him,--it was a very old street organ, playing "Adeste Fideles," (the Christmas Hymn) You would almost have smiled to hear how it groaned, and what labor and work it seemed to have to bring the tune out. The angel looked, and there was such a little boy, only about eight years old, turning the handle round and round.
His face was pale with cold and hunger; his fair face was only half covered by an old cap; a thin dress did not half protect him from the sharp freezing cold; but still he turned on and on without stopping, for he had only seven pence, and he knew if he went home without a shilling he should get no supper, and perhaps worse than that.
All day long he had been in the streets playing over all his little tunes, and almost crying himself every time "Adeste Fideles" came around.--So many people passed him by; sometimes they stopped for a moment to look at him, and then his heart would beat high with hope, and he would eagerly watch their hand.
Then they passed on, and the light would fade from his eyes, and "his heart grow sad again."--Night came at last with its stars, and the snow was frozen, and the air blew keen and sharp.
The street lamps were lighted, and the gas in the show windows.
More and more people passed him by; they walked quickly because of the cold, and did did not stay to think of the poor little boy or his music.
Still he turned round and round, and every now and then "Adeste Fideles" came in its turn.--None knew how the timid heart was shrinking from fear, or surely they would have given something from their abundance.
And as the night wore on, the hot, heavy tears fell down the pale face, and the tired arms almost refused to work.
"Oh, mother," said the child, with a great sigh and sob, "oh, if I might come to heaven to you."
Then the angel drew near; he held the light, and looked into the boy's heart. "Ah!" said he, when he saw what was there. "but I will be sure first."

Very slowly, very sadly the child turned his wearied footsteps home; lingering by the way, for he knew what would await him if he had not money enough, often staying to look in the shop windows, where the hot pies and cakes looked so tempting, and longing with all his hungry little heart for one; then counting his money over and over again so carefully, hoping he might have made a mistake before, and turning all his pockets over to see if he had not one half- penny left that he did not know of. No, there it all lay, only seven pence, and he had been all day in the cold and snow.
Wearily he lifted up his organ, and turned to go home.
Ah, me!
what sad thoughts were in that poor little heart; how bitter were the tears that fell so fast; well might the angel fancy as he followed him, that he heard more distinctly and pitifully the ripple of the stream.
While the child and the angel turn down streets and lanes and alleys, I will tell you who the boy was. His father and mother were poor Italians, and many years ago they left their beautiful sunny land and came to England to try to get their living.
They only had this one little boy, and he was called after the great and holy St. Bernard.--But he was so small and so pretty, with such fair hair and dark soft eyes, that he never went by any other name than Bernie.
His mother died when he was very young, and left him to his father.
And his dear kind father was everything to him. He amused him and played with him, and when Bernie was tired, he would take him in his arms, and sing songs of the beautiful Italy to him. Every morning the father used to go out with his organ and come home again in the evening, and the old woman where he lodged used to take care of Bernie.
All day he was so quiet and good, and when evening was coming he would stand near the street door and watch for his father, and when he saw him would run to meet him, and the poor father would often go without butter to his bread, or sugar to his tea, so as to be able to bring his little boy a nice cake or a bun home.
Then Bernie's bright eyes would sparkle, and he would clap his hands for joy. Ab, I cannot tell you how passionately the father loved this little boy, and he, poor child, had no one else to love; no one else ever spoke a kind word to him; so all his heart was fixed upon his dear father.

One cold winter poor Bernie's father was taken very ill, and could not go out with his organ.
He grew worse and worse, and the doctor and the priest both came, and said he could never get any better.
One day when he was alone with the boy, he called him to the bedside and said--"My dear Bernie, my poor boy, have they told you I am going?"
"Going where, father!"
"To heaven, I hope, my child."
"Oh, yes, they told me, but I did not mind, because I knew you would never go anywhere without me. You will take me, too, won't you?" and he fixed his eyes eagerly upon his father's face.

But the father could not answer.
How could he tell the lonely little boy that he would leave him forever, and that he would be alone in the wide world without one to love or care for him. He could only take him in his arms, and hold him to the heart so soon to be stilled for ever.
The child felt his father's burning face and hands growing colder.
"Bernie!" "Bernie!" he said, groping with his hand as though in darkness.
"I am here, father," said the boy, wondering.

Once, oh, yet once more, such is the power of love, the dying arms clasped him once again, and for the last time those loving lips kissed the boy's fair brow, and then, oh, then, the dear hands grew colder, and an awful stillness fell upon the white face.
"Father, father!" cried the child, in wild terror.

No answer.
For the first time the dear voice was silent to his cry; and when the priest came he found Bernie senseless from grief and fear, still clasping his dead father's hand.
And the doctor said it was the great and sudden emotion at the child's question, of which Bernie told him, that had snapped the slender thread of the poor father's life.

Poor, poor Bernie, they took his father, away, and laid him in the cold ground.
And he used to go every day to cry by his grave.--And sometimes he would lay his little head down upon the grass, and say so pitifully, "Oh, father, please let me come to Heaven."

Some people wanted Bernie to go to the workhouse; they said it was the proper place for such children as he. But the old woman where he lodged, said "No, if he will give me a shilling a-week, I will keep him, for he can go out with his organ."

So that was settled, and one bright summer's morning they put his poor lost father's organ in his hands, and sent him out to play.
At first it was a novelty to see such a little boy out playing, that people used to be very generous and pleased to give him a penny.--Then when they were quite used to it, they would pass him by without giving him anything.

The old woman, whose name was Bessy, was not cruel.
She rather liked Bernie, and would have been very kind to him if she had lived alone, but she had two big idle sons, who were very bad men, and who led the poor child a miserable life.
They used to send him out in the morning with a bit of bread, to last him the whole day. And then they made a cruel rule that if he came home with less than a shilling, he should have no supper.
Oh, my dear children, think of what that boy suffered from hunger; think how he must have trembled all day, for fear he should not have money enough.
So he went on for some time, and at last came Christmas Eve.
He cried when he first got up in the morning, for he remembered how last Christmas Eve his dear father had hurried home with a beautiful orange, and some warm pies, and had kissed him, and said, "Here is your Christmas feast, Bernie." Alas!
this Christmas Eve no one thought about him, or cared whether he lived or died, and he looked upon the snow, and then up to the stars, and asked, "Our Father who art in Heaven," to take him home.

The angel and the child went through a great part of the city until they came to the house where he lived.
How his poor little heart beat with fear as he opened the door quietly.
"Well," said a gruff voice, "and what have you got, young one?"
"Only seven pence," said Bernie, trembling in every limb.

And well he might; for a heavy hand struck a severe blow upon his little defenceless head.
Ah, me!
the same dear head that lay years ago upon his mother's heart, and lately upon his dead father's heart.
"Oh, please don't beat me; I am very sorry, but I could not help it; no one would give me anything."

"Because you never asked," said the man, with another blow.
Now, go up stairs, and remember, you have no supper; you do not earn your salt; go along, sir."

Very slowly the little fellow turned to go away.
The man was having a nice supper of hot meat, that smelt so savory and so tempting that it made the poor child more hungry than ever.
It was hissing and frying in a pan over the fire, and how good it looked to his eager eyes.
"Oh, I am so hungry, and it's Christmas Eve; might I have a bit of supper, please," he said, trembling, and timidly.

"I'll Christmas Eve you, if you talk that nonsense.
If you don't earn supper, you can't have it. Go up stairs."

So meekly and quietly he went, with such a look of hunger in his pale face, that the man's heart must have been harder than iron: as it was, when he returned to his comfortable supper after driving Bernie up to his garret, he seemed to try to satisfy his own conscience by saying--
"Those boys are so idle, one must be sharp with them."
"You need not starve him, if you are sharp," said the mother, "he looks bad enough now, without sending him hungry and cold to bed."
But the man went on eating, and the old woman durst not offer to take the child anything while he was about.

Wearily, wearily the poor boy mounted the steep stairs, until he came to his room.
And what a room it was, so cold, and so dirty, with a small iron bedstead, and a straw mattress with one blanket, nothing else, not even a chair.
Bernie put his dear organ safe in one corner of the room, said his prayers, and then lay down, faint and hungry and cold, on his miserable bed. Then, when he was quite alone, and he durst cry, he hid his little face in the blanket and cried, oh, such tears!
Even there he could smell the nice supper below, and every time the door opened he thought Bessy was coming to bring him some, but she never came; and then his poor heart sank again.
Ah, well might the angel think he heard the ripple of the stream louder and more pitiful than ever.

A strange feeling came over Bernie, his head seemed to be lighter and yet all on fire, his hands were burning hot, and his eyes so heavy he could not keep them open, and every limb ached as though he had been tearfully beaten.
"Oh, father, father," cried the lonely child, "do come to me, or else fetch me to Heaven; do you know how ill and hungry I am?"

The angel could bear it no longer, he drew near and held the light close to Bernie's heart; there could not be a more miserable child.--Nothing could be worse than this; poor, lonely, cold, hungry, alone, and no one to love him or care for him; no one even to speak a kind word to him; no one had ever kissed him since his father died.

The angel came nearer, he knelt by the bedside for a moment, and then stood by Bernie; he laid his cool, soft hand upon his hot brow and flushed face; the boy opened his eyes, and there, in place of the cold, dirty room, he saw a most beautiful angel, with a bright, sweet face, and kind, loving eyes, and soft white wings; and upon one finger there was something that looked like a large diamond.
Bernie was not afraid; no — those were the first eyes that looked kindly on him for so long.
"Bernie," said the angel, in a sweet, low voice, "my poor little boy, you are very miserable"
"I am, dear angel, the most miserable child in the world."
"I am come to help you, Bernie."

"Oh, angel, will you help me?
Oh, then, please do take me to my father."
"I will take you to God and your father, too; and you shall see your dear mother again, Bernie."
"Thank you, dear angel, now I am happy."

Then the angel took Bernie's hands, and folded them in his own; he breathed upon his face, and he felt no more cold or heat; he only saw the golden glory round the angel's head, and heard a faint distant sound of music; and something seemed floating through the room like fragrant incense.
"Say, 'Our Father,' Bernie."

"Now say after me--'Dear Jesus, who wert once a child, like me, take pity upon me, for I have known cold and misery, and hunger and thirst, and loneliness and sorrow.
I am sorry with all my heart, for all my many sins; I repent most bitterly of them.
I wish I had been a better boy. I offer to Thee all my troubles; and I beg of Thee, dear Lord, if it be Thy will, to let me come home to Thee.'--Are you willing to die, dear Bernie?"
"Yes; I am very willing."
"You wish to go to Heaven?"
"Yes; with all my heart."
"But if God willed for you to live much longer, and to suffer much more, would you be as willing?"
"Yes; for the love of Him, dear angel."

Then the angel drew nearer, and he laid Bernie's head upon his kind heart.
Whether he lay there moments or hours, the boy never knew; he only saw the glory bright, and the music sweeter.
He felt no pain, no care, only a dreamy longing to see something more glorious than he saw there.
Then the glory became so dazzling and bright, he could no longer bear it; and then the music, so sweet and near, he could distinguish the word "Hosanna."
"Close your eyes, Bernie," said the angel.

He did so; the angel gently pressed his hand upon them, something fluttered at Bernie's heart and on his lips, the light and music ascended, and the boy and the angel, together joined the "Hosanna" in Heaven.

There was a great sensation on the morrow, when the child was found dead.
They held an inquest, but the doctors could scarcely agree as to how he died, or what was his disease.
But they all wondered at the fair, marble face, with its angelical smile, and the white hands crossed upon the little heart.
The poor old woman cried very much, and was very grieved for little Bernie; and the cruel man never forgot that pitiful pleading voice.

Dear young friends, perhaps you think such tales are scarcely true.
When you are older and can read the papers, you will see stranger things than these; cruelty to little helpless children is not rare.
Will you little ones do all you can to atone for it, particularly this happy Christmas time, when you have such abundance of good things and kind friends?--Think of the poor and the helpless, and give something to comfort and cheer them.
